questions.text: With regards to the pasteurization of milk, which of the following tests is not related?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Iodine test

 

Explanation:

 

  • The iodine test is not directly related to the pasteurization of milk. It is a test used to detect the presence of starch in a substance. It involves adding iodine solution to the sample, and if starch is present, the solution will turn blue-black.

 

Incorrect Choices:

 

  • Phosphatase test (Option A): The phosphatase test is indeed related to the pasteurization of milk. Phosphatase is an enzyme naturally present in raw milk but is inactivated during the pasteurization process. By measuring the activity of phosphatase in milk, it can be determined if proper pasteurization has occurred. Therefore, this option is incorrect as the phosphatase test is directly related to pasteurization.

 

  • Standard plate count (Option C): The standard plate count is also related to the pasteurization of milk. It is a test used to determine the total number of viable microorganisms present in milk. By assessing the microbial load, the effectiveness of pasteurization in reducing bacterial contamination can be evaluated. This option is incorrect as the standard plate count is directly associated with assessing the pasteurization process.

 

  • Methylene blue reduction test (Option D): The methylene blue reduction test is used to assess the bacteriological quality of milk and the efficiency of pasteurization. It evaluates the reduction of methylene blue dye by the metabolic activity of microorganisms in milk. This test helps determine if pasteurization has effectively inhibited bacterial growth. Therefore, this option is incorrect as the methylene blue reduction test is directly related to pasteurization.

questions.text: Who is responsible for counseling and providing information to the patient, a 30-week primigravida experiencing reduced vision at night, who has been avoiding certain fruits during her pregnancy due to concerns about their potential abortifacient effects?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) ASHA

Explanation:

  • Although all of the above given can do this job but single best answer is ASHA Worker
  • The pregnant woman is likely to be suffering from Vitamin A deficiency due to poor intake of foods rich in vitamin A.
  • The primary duty of the ASHA worker is to go for home visits and to counsel regarding sanitation, nutrition, living conditions, and family welfare services.
  • She helps in mobilizing the community to access health care facilities available at PHC/Anganwadi/sub-center.

ASHA (Accredited Social Health Activist)

ASHA is a woman (married, divorced, or widowed) resident of the village, aged 25-45 years, with education up to 8th grade.

Population Norm for ASHA

The general norm is 1 ASHA per 1000 population. In tribal, hilly, and desert areas, this may be relaxed to 1 ASHA per habitation.

Role and Responsibilities of ASHA
  • Health Activist: Create awareness and provide information on health determinants, existing services, and the importance of health and family welfare.
  • Counselor: Provide counseling on birth preparedness, safe delivery, and family planning.
  • Mobilizer: Help the community access health services, such as immunizations, sanitation, and nutrition.
  • Provider: Offer basic care for common illnesses and first-aid, and act as a depot for essential medications.
  • Community Engagement: Work with village health committees and panchayats for planning and awareness.

Specific Responsibilities of ASHA
  • Promote health and sanitation practices.
  • Advise on child care, immunization, and reproductive health.
  • Assist with family planning and treatment of minor ailments.
  • Mobilize pregnant women and children to health services
  • Provide basic medical care and support for diarrhea, fever, and tuberculosis (under DOTS).
  • Serve as a depot holder for essential drugs and medical supplies.

Role and Integration with Anganwadi

The Anganwadi worker helps guide ASHA, particularly in organizing Health Day activities, mobilizing village women and children, and promoting nutrition and health education.

Role and Integration with ANMs (Auxiliary Nurse Midwives)

 

ANMs guide ASHA in areas like immunization, safe pregnancy, and health education, and assist in organizing Health Days. ANMs also help with training and monitor ASHA's performance.

 

ANM (Option A): ANM ensures thorough training of the ASHA worker.

AWW (Option B): They are part-time workers. She undergoes training for 4 months in various sectors like health, nutrition, and child development.

Trained birth attendant (Option D): They ensure safe delivery, monitor maternal and fetal well-being, promote a positive birthing experience by reducing stress and anxiety during labor, promote exclusive breastfeeding, and are trained to identify and rectify any labor complications.

questions.text: A poor farmer with a history of successive crop failure develops progressive spastic paraparesis, signs of upper motor neuron paralysis, and gait instability. Name the toxin responsible for this condition.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Beta-oxalyl-amino-alanine

Explanation:

  • The condition in the given case scenario is called Lathyrism, which is due to the toxin beta-oxalyl-amino-alanine present in Lathyrus seeds.

Lathyrism:

Causative agent
  • Beta-oxalyl amino alanine (BOAA) present in Lathyrus sativus
  • Significant exposure : >30% inclusion in diet over 2-6 months

Clinical features
  • Latent stage: preventive can be best implemented here
  • No stick stage: most common point of diagnosis
  • One-stick stage: muscular stiffness begins
  • Two-stick stage: will need crutches
  • Crawler stage: muscular atrophy sets in.

Treatment
  • Vitamin C prophylaxis: 500-1000 mg per day
  • Banning the crop

Toxin removal
  • Steeping method: soaking in hot water for 2 hours, drained and sun-dried.
  • Parboiling: overnight soaking in limewater.
  • Genetic approach: selecting variants with less BOAA content and cultivating the same.
  • Educating people.
  • Bringing socio-economic changes.

questions.text: You are administering vitamin A supplements to an 8-month-old infant for two consecutive days. What is the recommended dose?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 100,000 IU

Explanation:

  • For infants 6-11 months old, the recommended dose of Vitamin A supplementation is 100,000 IU for two consecutive days.
  • This is part of national immunization programs aimed at preventing Vitamin A deficiency, which can cause blindness and increase the risk of other infections.

 

25,000 IU (Option A): is incorrect because 25,000 IU is the recommended dose for children aged 12-59 months, not for infants under one year.

50,000 IU (Option B): is incorrect because 50,000 IU is not the standard dose for infants under 1 year. The appropriate dose for infants aged 6-11 months is 100,000 IU.

200,000 IU (Option D): is incorrect because this dose is generally used for children aged 1-5 years, and is too high for an infant aged 6-11 months.

questions.text: What vitamin deficiency leads to xerophthalmia, a condition characterized by dryness of the eyes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Vitamin A

Explanation:

  • Vitamin A deficiency is the primary cause of xerophthalmia, a condition that includes dry eyes and can progress to night blindness and corneal damage if untreated. Vitamin A plays a crucial role in maintaining the health of the cornea.

 

Vitamin B (Option B): is incorrect because vitamin B deficiencies, like B1, B6, or B12, do not cause xerophthalmia. These deficiencies are linked to neurological and hematological issues, not eye-related conditions.

Vitamin C (Option C): is incorrect because vitamin C deficiency leads to scurvy, which is characterized by symptoms such as bleeding gums, poor wound healing, and skin problems, but not xerophthalmia.

Vitamin D (Option D): is incorrect because vitamin D deficiency primarily leads to rickets in children or osteomalacia in adults, conditions that affect bone health, not the eyes.

questions.text: What is the likely reason for the food poisoning experienced by the worker in the groundnut factory who consumed spoiled groundnuts that were stored in the facility?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Aflatoxins

  • The likely reason for food poisoning in a worker who consumed spoiled groundnuts stored in the facility is: Aflatoxins
  • Aflatoxins are toxic compounds produced by Aspergillus flavus and Aspergillus parasiticus, fungi that grow on improperly stored food items such as groundnuts (peanuts), grains, and nuts in warm and humid conditions.

Aflatoxicosis:

Clinical features
  • Features of hepatotoxicity (jaundice, hepatomegaly)
  • Hepatocellular carcinoma

Causative agent
  • Infestation of Aspergillus flavus and Aspergillus parasiticus over stored rice, wheat, and corn
  • Produce mycotoxins: aflatoxin B1 & G1 (both are hepatotoxic & carcinogenic)

Risk factors
  • Storage temperature of 11 to 37 degree Celsius
  • Moisture content >16%

Prevention
  • Educating people
  • Moisture content <10% during storage

Beta oxalyl amino alanine (Option A): a neurotoxic compound in certain plants like Lathyrus sativus seeds, leads to Lathyrism when consumed excessively over time. It is not associated with groundnuts.

Smoke inhalation (Option B): While exposure to smoke may cause health problems, it does not explain the specific symptoms of food poisoning experienced by the worker.

Sanguinarine (Option C): is an alkaloid found in certain plants, including bloodroot and other members of the Papaveraceae family.

questions.text: If Bajra is mixed with black seeds, what is used to separate them?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - 20% salt water

  • A 20% salt water solution creates a density that makes black seeds sink, while Bajra seeds stay afloat, making the separation easy.

Ergotism:

  • Ergot is a fungus (Claviceps purpurea) that infects food grains such as bajra, rye, sorghum, and wheat during their flowering stages.
  • Consumption of ergot-infested grains can lead to ergotism, characterised by acute symptoms such as nausea, repeated vomiting, giddiness, and drowsiness lasting up to 24 to 48 hours.
  • In chronic cases, ergotism may cause painful cramps in limbs and peripheral gangrene due to vasoconstriction of capillaries.
  • Modern high-yielding varieties of bajra are more susceptible to ergot infestation.
  • Infested grains can be removed in 20% salt water, hand-picking, or air floatation.
  • The upper safe limit for ergot alkaloids in food material is 0.05 mg per 100 grams.

questions.text: Which of the following factors can contribute to the development of malnutrition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Infectious diseases

Explanation:

  • Infectious diseases significantly contribute to malnutrition by increasing metabolic demands, reducing appetite, impairing nutrient absorption, and causing nutrient loss.
  • Common infections such as diarrhea, tuberculosis, parasitic infections, and respiratory infections lead to weight loss, muscle wasting, and stunting.
  • Recurrent infections create a vicious cycle where malnutrition weakens immunity, leading to more infections.

Role of Infectious Diseases in Malnutrition:

Infection

Effect on Nutrition

Diarrheal diseases

Causes fluid and nutrient loss, leading to dehydration and malabsorption.

Tuberculosis (TB)

Increases catabolism (muscle breakdown), leading to weight loss.

Parasitic infections (e.g., hookworm, giardiasis)

Causes iron deficiency anemia, protein loss, and malabsorption.

Measles

Leads to vitamin A deficiency, impairing immune function.

 

Child rearing (Option A): While child rearing practices can influence nutrition (e.g., breastfeeding practices, introduction of complementary foods), it does not directly cause malnutrition in the same way infections can. Poor child rearing practices may contribute, but they are not a primary factor.

Food habits (Option C): Food habits certainly play a role in nutrition, but they alone do not directly cause malnutrition unless they are extreme (e.g., insufficient intake of essential nutrients). In general, food habits are more of a contributing factor rather than a primary cause.

Socioeconomic factors (Option D): Socioeconomic factors, such as poverty, can significantly affect access to adequate food and healthcare, contributing to malnutrition. However, socioeconomic factors are broader and often contribute in conjunction with other factors like food habits and infectious diseases.

questions.text: Which of the following substances should be eaten to prevent thiamine deficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Rice and wheat:

  • While refined rice and wheat are not the best sources of thiamine, whole grains and fortified products are better at preventing thiamine deficiency.
  • Rice and wheat, when consumed in their whole form (i.e., brown rice and whole wheat), provide a better source of thiamine and can help in preventing thiamine deficiency compared to the other options listed.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Curd: While curd (yogurt) is a good source of various nutrients, including calcium and protein, it is not a significant source of thiamine. It does not play a major role in preventing thiamine deficiency.

Option C - Salad: Salads typically consist of vegetables and fruits, which can provide a range of vitamins and minerals. However, thiamine content in salads varies depending on the specific vegetables and fruits used. In general, salad is not a primary source of thiamine.

Option D - Sabji (Aloo): Aloo (potato) is commonly used in sabji (vegetable dishes) and is a good source of thiamine compared to some other foods. However, for a more substantial prevention of thiamine deficiency, other foods rich in thiamine should be included.

questions.text: What is the most relevant information that should be obtained from the medical history of a patient from Chhattisgarh who is experiencing gradual muscle weakness and spasms in the legs, and exhibits only motor impairment upon examination?

choices.text: History of similar illness in the past

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) History of diet.

Explanation:

  • The patient is from Chhattisgarh, a region known for outbreaks of Lathyrism, a neurological disorder caused by the consumption of Lathyrus sativus (Khesari dal).
  • Lathyrism is characterized by gradual-onset spastic paraparesis (muscle weakness and spasms in the legs), with only motor impairment and no sensory loss.
  • The toxin β-N-oxalyl-L-α,β-diaminopropionic acid (β-ODAP) in Khesari dal causes upper motor neuron (UMN) damage, leading to progressive spastic paralysis.

Features of Lathyrism:

Feature

Findings

Cause

Excessive consumption of Lathyrus sativus (Khesari dal)

Region

Endemic in Chhattisgarh, Madhya Pradesh, Bihar, Odisha

Symptoms

Gradual-onset spastic paraparesis, hyperreflexia

Sensory Involvement

Absent (pure motor disorder)

Prevention

Dietary restriction, government bans on Khesari dal

 

History of similar illness in the past (Option A): While a history of similar illness may be relevant in some cases, this patient's symptoms are more likely due to a dietary issue rather than a recurrent illness.

History of fever (Option B): Fever could indicate an infection or inflammation but isn't the primary concern given the gradual onset of symptoms. The absence of fever makes this less relevant in the current context.

History of vaccination (Option C): While vaccination is important for preventing diseases like poliomyelitis, in this case, the gradual onset of muscle weakness and spasms suggests a nutritional or metabolic cause rather than a vaccine-preventable disease.

questions.text: Which statement is correct regarding the reference woman represents the average healthy woman's nutritional needs and is used as a standard for setting the RDA ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Weight 55 kgs

Explanation:

The reference woman represents the average healthy woman's nutritional needs and is used as a standard for setting the Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA). This reference is crucial for determining the nutrient requirements of the general population.

  • Weight 55 kgs: The reference woman is typically assumed to have a body weight of 55 kg (121 lbs). This value is used to determine the average energy and nutrient requirements.

 

Height 1.73 m (Option B): While height is a factor in determining nutritional needs, the reference woman is generally assumed to have a height of around 1.60 m (not 1.73 m).

Works 10 hours/day (Option C): The reference woman is not assumed to work for a specific number of hours each day. Nutritional requirements can vary depending on physical activity, but the reference is typically for a woman with moderate activity levels.

Age of 18-25 years (Option D): The reference woman is not specifically limited to this age range. Nutritional needs are assessed based on a range of factors, including age, but the reference woman is generally used as an average for adult women (not limited to a specific age group).

questions.text: Which of the following food items contains the lowest amount of iron?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option D- Milk

Explanation:

Sources rich in iron:

Two types: haem-iron and non-haem iron.

  • Haem iron
    • Haem iron is better absorbed than non-haem iron.
    • Found in liver (Option A ruled out), meat, poultry, and fish.
    • Promotes absorption of non-haem iron in plant foods eaten concurrently.
  • Non-Haem iron:
    • It is found in plant-based foods such as cereals, green leafy vegetables (Option B ruled out), legumes (Option C ruled out), nuts, oilseeds, jaggery, and dried fruits.
  • Additional Iron Sources: Cooking in iron vessels can significantly contribute to dietary iron in some areas.
  • Iron Content in Milk:
    • Low in all mammalian species. (Option D)
    • Breast milk contains less than 0.2 mg/dL but has good bioavailability.

Bioavailability and Absorption Inhibitors:

  • Non-haem iron absorption is hindered by phytates, oxalates, carbonates, phosphates, and dietary fibre.
  • Foods like milk, eggs, and tea also inhibit iron absorption.
  • Indian vegetarian diets often contain high levels of these inhibitors (e.g., phytates in bran, phosphates in egg yolk, tannin in tea, and oxalates in vegetables).

questions.text: Which of the following foods has the maximum biological value?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D) Egg

Explanation:

  • Eggs are often regarded as the gold standard of protein due to their high biological value. They are considered a complete protein source as they contain all essential amino acids in optimal ratios.
  • Egg protein is highly bioavailable and contains important nutrients such as vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants.

 

Egg

Importance
  • Eggs are highly nutritious and rich in protein, essential vitamins, & minerals.
  • They support muscle building, brain health, and overall wellness.
  • NPU of egg is 96 (~ almost equal to 100)

Rule of 6
  • 6 grams of protein
  • 6 grams of fat
  • 60 calories per large egg
  • 6 essential vitamins (A, B2, B12, D, E, K)
  • 60 grams average weight

Others:

  • 6x5=30 mg Calcium
  • 6x0.25=1.5mg Iron

 

Eggs are easy to digest and have high bioavailability, meaning the body can efficiently absorb and utilise the protein.

 

Net Protein Utilization (NPU):

  • Digestibility coefficient (external indicator) x Biological value (internal indicator) / 100
  • Percentage of the ingested nitrogen retained in the body
  • 1 gm protein = 6.25gm nitrogen
  • NPU Indian diet: 50-80

 

Pulses (Option A): Pulses, such as lentils, chickpeas, and beans, are a rich source of plant-based protein. While they provide essential amino acids, they are generally considered to have lower biological value compared to animal-based proteins. This is because pulses are deficient in one or more essential amino acids, particularly methionine.

Soybean (Option B): While soybean protein is of higher quality among plant-based sources, it still does not match the BV of animal-based proteins due to slightly lower digestibility and bioavailability.

Milk (Option C): Milk has a high BV (around 85–90) because it contains all essential amino acids in a good ratio and is easily digestible. Milk protein, particularly casein and whey, is of high quality and supports tissue repair and growth effectively. However, its biological value is slightly lower than egg.

questions.text: A patient whose diet mainly consists of pulses and rice presents with bowed legs (stick deformity). Which of the following vitamins could have prevented this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Vitamin D

Explanation:

  • The patient’s diet (mainly pulses and rice) is low in vitamin D and calcium-rich foods. Bowed legs (“stick deformity”) in this context indicate rickets, a disease of defective bone mineralization in children caused primarily by vitamin D deficiency. Vitamin D is essential for calcium and phosphate absorption; its deficiency leads to soft bones and deformities.

Vitamin D & Rickets:

  • Sources:
    • Endogenous synthesis in skin via sunlight (UVB rays).
    • Dietary: fortified milk, egg yolk, fish liver oils.
  • Functions:
    • Enhances intestinal absorption of calcium and phosphate.
    • Promotes bone mineralization.
    • Modulates immune function.
  • Deficiency Effects:
    • In children → Rickets: bowed legs, rachitic rosary, widening of wrists/ankles, delayed closure of fontanelle.
    • In adults → Osteomalacia.
  • Risk Factors:
    • Diet lacking in dairy/fortified foods.
    • Limited sunlight exposure.
    • Malabsorption syndromes.
  • Prevention:
    • Adequate sunlight exposure.
    • Vitamin D supplementation in high-risk groups.

Vitamin C (Option C) – Deficiency causes scurvy (bleeding gums, poor wound healing); does not cause bowed legs.

questions.text: In a 30-year-old male presenting with bleeding gums and iron deficiency anemia, which vitamin deficiency would you anticipate?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Vitamin C:

  • Vitamin C deficiency, also known as scurvy, is characterized by symptoms such as bleeding gums, joint pain, and fatigue. Vitamin C is essential for collagen synthesis, and its deficiency leads to impaired connective tissue integrity, resulting in bleeding from the gums and other mucous membranes.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Vitamin A: Vitamin A deficiency is known to cause night blindness and can affect vision. It is not directly associated with bleeding gums or iron deficiency anemia.

Option B - Vitamin B1: Vitamin B1 deficiency can lead to conditions like beriberi, which primarily affects the nervous system and cardiovascular system. It is not directly linked to bleeding gums or iron deficiency anemia.

Option D - Vitamin D: Vitamin D deficiency can result in conditions like rickets or osteomalacia, affecting bone health. It is not typically associated with bleeding gums or iron deficiency anemia.

questions.text: A mother comes with her child who has papules on the extensor surfaces of the skin, which resolve with the administration of vitamins A and C and essential amino acids. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Phrynoderma:

  • Phrynoderma is characterized by papular lesions on the extensor surfaces, which can improve with vitamin A supplementation. The resolution of symptoms with the administration of vitamins A and C, along with essential amino acids, is consistent with this diagnosis.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Rickets: This is a condition resulting from vitamin D deficiency, leading to weak and soft bones in children. Symptoms include bone deformities and growth retardation, but it does not typically present with papules on the extensor surfaces.

Option C - Kwashiorkor: This is a form of protein-energy malnutrition characterized by edema, irritability, and skin changes. It usually involves more generalized symptoms of malnutrition rather than isolated papules that resolve with vitamins and amino acids.

Option D - Marasmus: This is another form of severe malnutrition caused by a deficiency in caloric intake, leading to severe weight loss and muscle wasting. It does not present with papules but rather with severe overall wasting.

questions.text: A man presented with bilateral swelling of his legs, diarrhoea, and dyspnea. He has a history of consuming mustard oil from a local vendor. Which test should be performed by the health inspector to check for the adulterant?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option A) Paper Chromatography Test

 

Explanation:

The above clinical scenario suggests epidemic dropsy, commonly occurring when mustard oil is contaminated with argemone oil. Paper chromatography is the most sensitive test for detecting the presence of argemone oil in edible oils. It helps identify the adulterant based on the separation and visualization of specific components.

 

Epidemic dropsy:

 

Clinical features

Bilateral leg swelling, diarrhoea, dyspnoea, features of glaucoma and heart failure even up to death.

Causative agent

Sanguinarine (toxic alkaloid present in argemone oil).

Detection of contamination
  • Nitric acid test: the presence of a red-brown ring when added to the sample oil indicates the presence of argemone oil.
  • Paper chromatography test. Most sensitive and better than nitric acid test (Option A) (Option B ruled out)

Prevention
  • Accidental contamination: removing argemone weeds growing among oilseed crops.
  • Deliberate contamination: enforcing Prevention of Food Adulteration Act.

 

Methylene Blue Reduction Test (Option C): This test is used to measure the bacterial contamination of milk and is not relevant to detecting oil adulterants.

questions.text: A 5-year-old has the following anthropometric findings: Weight/age < -3.2 SD, Height/age < -2.5 SD, Weight/height < -1.7 SD. Under which of the following categories would this child be classified?

  • Weight/height < -1.7 SD: This indicates wasting. Wasting is typically a sign of acute malnutrition, but in this context, it is less severe compared to the other measures.

  • Given the severity of the indicators for weight/age and height/age, which are more pronounced, the primary issue appears to be chronic malnutrition.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Acute malnutrition:

  • Acute malnutrition is primarily indicated by significant wasting (weight/height < -2 SD). Although the child has wasting (weight/height < -1.7 SD), the more severe indicators are weight/age and height/age, pointing more towards a chronic issue rather than an acute one.
  • Acute on chronic malnutrition would be considered if both stunting (chronic) and wasting (acute) were severely present. In this case, the degree of wasting (weight/height < -1.7 SD) is not as severe as the stunting and underweight indicators, which suggests that the primary issue is chronic.

Option C - Acute on chronic malnutrition:

  • Acute on chronic malnutrition would be considered if both stunting (chronic) and wasting (acute) were severely present. In this case, the degree of wasting (weight/height < -1.7 SD) is not as severe as the stunting and underweight indicators, which suggests that the primary issue is chronic.

Option D - Severe malnutrition:

  • Severe malnutrition is a general term and could refer to either acute or chronic malnutrition. While the child is indeed severely malnourished, specifying chronic malnutrition is more accurate given the primary indicators of weight/age and height/age.

questions.text: A 3 year old child came in the opd with severe diarrhea , vomiting, skin, deeply sunken eyes and no urine output. On examination baby is severely dehydrated, lethargic,high respiratory rate and BP of 80/60mmHg. Which fluid is given for management?

questions.text:
What BMI value is generally considered extremely low and associated with a higher risk of severe health complications in men?

a. BMI < 10 b. BMI < 15 c. d.
questions.solution:
The correct answer is:

Option A. BMI < 15

Explanation:

BMI (Body Mass Index) is a numerical value calculated based on an individual's weight and height. A BMI below 15 is considered extremely low and is associated with a significantly increased risk of severe health complications. This level of underweight can indicate malnutrition and a host of potential health problems, including:

  1. Weakened immune system: Malnutrition can lead to a compromised immune system, making the individual more susceptible to infections and diseases.

  2. Organ damage: Extremely low BMI can result in damage to vital organs, including the heart, liver, and kidneys, which can lead to organ failure.

  3. Nutritional deficiencies: Severely low BMI is often indicative of severe nutritional deficiencies, including deficiencies in essential vitamins and minerals.

  4. Muscle wasting: It can result in muscle wasting and overall weakness, affecting mobility and daily functioning.

  5. Increased risk of mortality: Extremely low BMI is associated with a significantly higher risk of mortality, especially if it is sustained over time.

It's important to note that the specific threshold for severe health risk can vary depending on an individual's unique circumstances, such as age, underlying health conditions, and muscle mass. However, a BMI below 15 is generally considered a critical indicator of extreme underweight and associated health risks. It is important for individuals with such low BMIs to seek medical attention and nutritional support to address these health concerns.

Options B, C, and D represent BMI values that are not considered extremely low, and they do not typically pose the same level of health risk associated with a BMI below 15.

questions.text: What is the cause of Wernicke encephalopathy?

questions.text: What is the most commonly used method of pasteurization nowadays?

  • "High temperature and short time (HTST) method" is currently the most common pasteurization method.
  • Pasteurization is a heat treatment process used to eliminate or reduce the presence of harmful microorganisms in food and beverages while maintaining their quality.
  • There are different pasteurization methods, but the high temperature and short time method (also known as HTST or flash pasteurization) is the most widely employed method today.
  • Milk is rapidly heated to a temperature of about 72 degree Celsius, is held at that temperature for not less than 15 seconds, and is then rapidly cooled to 4 degree Celsius.
  • This method can pasteurize very large quantities of milk per hour.

Incorrect Options:

Holder (VAT) method: The Holder method, also known as the vat pasteurization method, involves heating milk or other liquids to a specified temperature and holding it at that temperature for a fixed duration. While this method was historically used, it is not as common today as the HTST method.

Option B. Ultra high temperature method: The ultra-high temperature (UHT) method involves heating food or beverages to a very high temperature, typically above 135 degrees Celsius (275 degrees Fahrenheit), for a very short period, usually a few seconds. UHT pasteurization is commonly used for products that need extended shelf life without refrigeration. While the UHT method is widely used for some products, such as long-life milk, it is not the most common method overall.

Option D. Low temperature and long time method: The low temperature and long time (LTLT) method, also known as batch pasteurization, involves heating milk or other liquids at lower temperatures for a longer duration compared to the HTST method. This method is commonly used for certain dairy products, such as artisanal or specialty cheeses, where maintaining the flavor and texture is crucial. However, it is not the most commonly used method in general food and beverage processing.

questions.text: How does the protein content of human milk compare to that of cow milk?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B:

"3-4 times less than cow milk" is the protein content of human milk as compared to cow milk.

  • Human milk and cow milk have different compositions to meet the nutritional needs of their respective species.
  • Human Milk: Human milk is specifically designed to meet the nutritional requirements of human infants. It contains a lower protein content compared to cow milk. On average, human milk contains approximately 1 gram of protein per 100 milliliters.
  • Cow Milk: Cow milk is intended to provide the necessary nutrients for the growth and development of calves. It has a higher protein content compared to human milk. Cow milk typically contains around 3-4 grams of protein per 100 milliliters.
  • The lower protein content in human milk is appropriate for the digestive capabilities and growth patterns of human infants. Human milk is easier to digest, and the lower protein content ensures that infants' kidneys are not burdened with excessive protein metabolism.

questions.text: According to WHO, marker for obesity Index is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A:

"Quetelet index" is the marker for obesity index according to the World Health Organization (WHO).

  • The Quetelet index, also known as the Body Mass Index (BMI), is a widely used measurement to assess obesity and overweight in individuals. Here's why it is considered the marker for obesity index according to WHO:
  • BMI Calculation: The Quetelet index or BMI is calculated by dividing an individual's weight in kilograms by the square of their height in meters (BMI = weight in kg / height in meters²). This index provides a numerical value that correlates with body fatness and is commonly used to classify individuals into different categories, such as underweight, normal weight, overweight, and obesity.
  • Accepted International Standard: The BMI has been adopted as an international standard by various health organizations, including the WHO. It is widely used as a screening tool for assessing the prevalence of overweight and obesity in populations and for monitoring trends over time.
  • Health Risk Assessment: The BMI is considered an indicator of body fatness and is associated with various health risks. Higher BMI values are generally associated with an increased risk of chronic conditions such as cardiovascular diseases, type 2 diabetes, certain cancers, and musculoskeletal disorders.

questions.text: Which is the most suitable indicator to determine the nutritional value of protein?
questions.solution:
Correct Option  A:

"Serum albumin concentration" is the best index for the calculation of the nutrient value of protein.

Serum albumin concentration is commonly used as an indicator of protein nutritional status and is often included in assessments of overall nutritional status. Here's why it is considered the best index for calculating the nutrient value of protein:

  • Protein Transport and Function: Albumin is the most abundant protein in the blood and plays a crucial role in transporting nutrients, including amino acids, hormones, and fatty acids, throughout the body. It also contributes to maintaining oncotic pressure and regulating fluid balance. Monitoring serum albumin concentration provides insights into the body's protein status and its ability to maintain these essential functions.
  • Long Half-Life: Serum albumin has a relatively long half-life of about 20 days. This means that changes in serum albumin concentration reflect more prolonged changes in protein intake and synthesis rather than short-term fluctuations. It allows for a more accurate assessment of the long-term protein nutritional status of an individual.
  • Availability of Laboratory Tests: Measuring serum albumin concentration is a relatively straightforward and widely available laboratory test. It can be easily performed using routine blood tests, making it a practical and cost-effective measure for evaluating protein nutritional status.

Incorrect Option:

Option B. Arm-muscle circumference: Arm-muscle circumference is often used as an indicator of muscle mass and can be affected by factors other than protein intake, such as physical activity and body fat percentage. It does not directly measure protein nutritional status or provide information about protein synthesis or breakdown.

Option C. Creatinine-height index: The creatinine-height index is used to estimate muscle mass and assess muscle wasting. It is primarily used in specific clinical settings, such as in patients with kidney disease, and is not a direct measure of protein nutritional status or the nutrient value of protein intake.

Option D. Serum transferrin level: Serum transferrin is a protein involved in iron transport. While it can provide information about iron status and iron deficiency, it is not specific to protein nutritional status or the overall nutrient value of protein intake.

  • Keshan's disease is a condition characterized by the inflammation of the heart muscle (myocarditis), primarily affecting children and young women. It was first identified in Keshan County, China, hence the name.
  • The main cause of Keshan's disease is believed to be a deficiency of selenium, an essential trace element. Selenium is an important component of several enzymes involved in antioxidant defense mechanisms and the maintenance of heart muscle function.
  • When selenium levels are low, the heart becomes more susceptible to damage from free radicals and viral infections. This can lead to myocarditis and subsequent heart failure, which are the hallmark features of Keshan's disease.

Incorrect choices:

Option D: Iron: Iron deficiency is commonly associated with anemia, but it is not the cause of Keshan's disease. Iron is necessary for the production of hemoglobin, which carries oxygen in the blood.

questions.text: What type of anemia is caused by a deficiency of Vitamin B12?
questions.solution:
Correct option

Option B. 

  • Vitamin B12 deficiency can lead to macrocytic hypochromic anemia. This type of anemia is characterized by red blood cells that are larger than normal (macrocytic) and have reduced hemoglobin content (hypochromic).
  • Vitamin B12 is essential for the production of healthy red blood cells. It plays a key role in the synthesis of DNA and in the maturation of red blood cells in the bone marrow.
  • Deficiency of vitamin B12 can result in ineffective DNA synthesis and impaired maturation of red blood cells, leading to the characteristic features of macrocytic hypochromic anemia.

Incorrect Options

Option A. Microcytic hypochromic anemia (choice A) is typically associated with iron deficiency anemia, where red blood cells are smaller and have reduced hemoglobin content.

Option C. Normocytic normochromic anemia (choice C) refers to anemia with normal-sized red blood cells and normal hemoglobin content. It can be caused by various factors such as chronic diseases, kidney problems, and bone marrow disorders.

Option D. None of the above is an incorrect answer as B is the correct answer

questions.text: What methods would you employ to identify Vitamin A Deficiency in a school setting?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option B. 

  • Screening for Vitamin A deficiency in a school setting can be done through the identification of clinical signs and symptoms associated with the deficiency. One of the early signs of Vitamin A deficiency is night blindness, which refers to the inability or difficulty to see in low light conditions or at night. Night blindness occurs due to the impaired functioning of the retina, which is responsible for vision in dim light.
  • By asking individuals, particularly school children, about their ability to see in low light conditions or at night, healthcare providers or school health personnel can screen for the presence of night blindness. Children who report difficulties with night vision are likely to have an underlying Vitamin A deficiency.

Incorrect Options

Option A. Retinol: Retinol is a form of Vitamin A, but it is not a specific screening method for Vitamin A deficiency. Retinol levels can be measured in blood samples to assess overall Vitamin A status, but this is not typically used as a screening tool in a school setting.

Option C. Carotene: Carotene, a precursor to Vitamin A, can be found in certain foods such as carrots, sweet potatoes, and leafy greens. However, assessing carotene levels is not a practical screening method for Vitamin A deficiency in a school setting.

Option D. Bitot spots: Bitot spots are a clinical manifestation of Vitamin A deficiency and appear as foamy, white patches on the conjunctiva of the eye. While the presence of Bitot spots may indicate Vitamin A deficiency, their detection requires a close examination of the eyes, which may not be feasible in a school screening scenarioC

questions.solution:

  • In the case of Marasmus, which is a form of severe acute malnutrition characterized by overall wasting and severe weight loss, the MUAC measurement is significantly reduced. The cut off value for MUAC in Marasmus is generally set at 11.5 mm or less.
  • Therefore, in the given options, the correct answer is 11.5.
  • A MUAC measurement less than 11.5 cm indicates severe wasting and is consistent with the diagnosis of Marasmus.

  • MUAC values of 17, 19, or 21 cm would indicate a healthier or more normal nutritional status, rather than the characteristic feature of Marasmus.

questions.text: What is the value of MAC in cases of severe malnutrition?
questions.solution:
Option D: 11.5 cms

  • This choice represents the cutoff for severe acute malnutrition according to the WHO guidelines. A MAC measurement of 11.5 cms or less would indeed indicate severe malnutrition.
  • Mid-upper arm circumference (MAC) is a commonly used anthropometric measurement to assess nutritional status, particularly for identifying severe malnutrition in children. MAC provides an estimate of muscle and fat stores in the upper arm and is an indicator of body composition and nutritional reserves.
  • In severe malnutrition, the MAC measurement is typically below a certain cutoff point. The World Health Organization (WHO) defines a MAC of less than 11.5 cms as a criterion for severe acute malnutrition in children aged 6-59 months.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: 14.5 cms

  • A MAC measurement of 14.5 cms would not be indicative of severe malnutrition. This value is within the normal range and does not suggest severe wasting or nutritional deficiency.

Option B: 13.5 cms

  • Similar to the previous choice, a MAC measurement of 13.5 cms would still fall within the normal range and would not indicate severe malnutrition.

Option C: 12.5 cms

  • MAC equal to or greater than 125 mm(12.5cms ) indicates No Acute Malnutrition
  • Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM): MAC less than 115 mm.
  • Moderate Acute Malnutrition (MAM): MAC between 115 mm and 125 mm.

questions.text: Which of the following options can be employed for the treatment of Kesari dal toxicity?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option C: 

  • Kesari dal (Lathyrus sativus) is a legume that is widely consumed in India and other countries. When consumed in large quantities over time, the dal contains a neurotoxin called beta-N-oxalyl-L-alpha-beta diaminopropionic acid (BOAA), which can cause a neurological disorder called lathyrism.
  • Vitamin C, also known as ascorbic acid, plays a role in lathyrism due to its potential protective effects against the toxic effects of β-ODAP. β-ODAP is known to induce oxidative stress and damage to neurons. Vitamin C is an antioxidant that can counteract oxidative stress by neutralizing harmful free radicals and protecting cells from damage.

Incorrect choices

  • Option a: Some evidence suggests that sodium bicarbonate may exacerbate the effects of Kesari dal toxicity. This is due to the fact that bicarbonate can increase ODAP absorption from the gastrointestinal tract and thus increase its toxicity. As a result, using sodium bicarbonate to treat Kesari dal toxicity is generally not advised.
  • Option b: There is no evidence that vitamin A has any effect on Kesari dal toxicity or Lathyrism. However, adequate vitamin A intake is required for healthy vision, immune system function, and cell growth and differentiation.
  • Option d: Kesari Dal toxicity is not treated with IV immunoglobulin because it is not a viral or immune-mediated condition. It is most commonly used to treat autoimmune and immune-mediated disorders, as well as some cases of primary immunodeficiency disorders.
